poem:
Title: "Taste of Tomorrow"

In tomorrow's meal we cradle hope,
Sustainable seeds in furrows cope.
In minds and fields, we duly till,
To bear the weight of a ten-trillion bill. 

Feast not in folly, but in wise repair,
Harvest of health blooms in clear air.
On borrowed time, we've fed our trust,
Untangle tomorrows, in the soil's thrust.

A bite of future, nature breathes,
In the echo of the leaf and sheaves.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Move to sustainable food systems could bring $10tn benefits a year, study finds A shift towards a more sustainable global food system could create up to $10tn (£7.9tn) of benefits a year, improve human health and ease the climate crisis, according to the most comprehensive economic study of its type. It found that existing food systems destroyed more value than they created due to hidden environmental and medical costs, in effect, borrowing from the future". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
